_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0  Executive Summary                                                                                                                                                       City of Yreka (COY) is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for its employees, the public, and the environment.  As part of this commitment, COY has established a system to help ensure safe operations of its regulated processes.  One component of this system is a Risk Management Program (RMProgram) that is designed to manage the risks at COY?s regulated facilities. Additionally, COY's Risk Management Plan (RMP) complies with all requirements of the California Accidental Release Prevention Program; the California OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standards; and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) requirements.

COY?s RMP consists of these three major elements:
1. A hazard assessment to aid in understanding the potential off-site consequences of hypothetical accidental releases, and an assessment of accidents that have occurred during the past five years associated with the use of substances regulated by the RMProgram Rule.
2. A prevention program to assist in maintaining and safely operating any processes containing more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance.
3. An emergency response program to help respond to an accidental release of a regulated substance from the covered process.

Information further describing these elements is provided in COY's RMP.

Although this RMP assists COY in providing assurance that the Water Pumping Station (WPS) facility is maintained and operated in a safe manner, it is only one component of their overall safety program.  In fact, COY has a comprehensive safety program in place establishing many levels of safeguards against the release of a hazardous substance, and injuries and damage resulting from a release of a hazardous substance. Additionally, COY has a Safety Director who initiates safety committee walkthroughs, and obtains ou

tside contractors to assist with maintenance and safety related issues regarding their regulated processes.

COY has limited its use of hazardous substances this facility. Before using a hazardous substance at COY's WPS facility, less hazardous alternatives are considered. When a hazardous substance is used, COY considers the potential for this substance to adversely affect their employees, the public, and the environment, and takes steps to prevent such effects.

COY works to prevent hazardous substance releases (chlorine gas) from its treatment facility.  The WPS facility is very well maintained, and the facility and process equipment were designed, built, and are being operated to reduce the likelihood of an accidental release. Industry and government standards were adhered to in the original design, construction, and operation of the facility and its process equipment, and current regulations are adhered to in new designs, construction, and operations of the regulated processes.

COY limits damage from a release, if such a release should occur, by training specific employees to respond to an accidental release.  In addition, COY works closely with the COY Fire and Police Departments, the Shasta Cascade Hazardous Materials Response Team (SCHMRT), and the Siskiyou County Environmental Health Department (SCEHD) to help ensure that injuries and/or environmental damage will be minimal, if a release from a regulated substance should occur.

The safety program at COY consists of a number of elements that conform to CalARP Program 3 requirements.  

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

COY is committed to the safety of its workers, the public, and the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous and regulated substances.  COY implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances. These controls include training programs for personnel; programs to help ensure saf

ety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of processes at the facility; and programs to manage the risks at facilities that store and use regulated substances.

In the event of an accidental release, COY's trainied responders, the COY Fire and Police Departments, and the SCHMRT will work to control and contain the spill or release in a manner that will be safe for the responders and the employees, and will help prevent injury to the public and minimize damage to the environment.  If an accidental release occurs, COY will revise Sections 5 and 6 of the RMP to include information about the accident and the related incident investigation and provide it to EPA within six months.  Additionally, the expected date of completion of changes due to the accident investigation will be incorporated into the RMP and submitted to EPA within six months of the accident.

COY provides response training to specific personnel, designates an emergency response coordinator to oversee response activities, and coordinates response efforts with the COY Fire and Police Departments, the SCHMRT, and the SCEHD.  COY and the Fire Department conducted an emergency response training exercise on February 28, 2005, and will be conducting an additional emergency response training exercise in the near future. COY responders will also be required to be certified for using respirators, and the proper PPE for responding to a release from the regulated substance.

To effectively implement these policies, COY has established a management system headed by the Public Works Director (Emergency Response Coordinator) along with the Water Manager, which have oversight for the WPS facility to oversee safety-related and emergency response activities.  These Managers all report to the City Manager.

1.2 COY?s Regulated Substances Handled and Source Information

COY?s WPS facility serves the City of Yreka and a few adjacent communities surrounding the area.  As part of the water filtration and trea

tment processes, chlorine gas is used and stored in sufficient quantities to be covered by the CalARP Program, California OSHA Process Safety Management Standards, and U.S. EPA RMP requirements.  COY's WPS contains approximately 4,000-pounds of chlorine gas (2 one-ton cylinders) within the chlorine process room.  

1.3 Off-Site Consequence Analysis (Appendix A of the RMP)

An Off-site Consequence Analysis (OCA) was prepared to address worst-case and alternative worst-case release scenarios for chlorine gas from COY?s WPS facility. The complete off-site consequence analysis is presented in Appendix A of the RMP, and for safety reasons the OCA maps should not be released without prior approval from the City of Yreka.

1.4 Mitigation Measures

COY has implemented administrative controls and mitigation measures at its facilities in order to minimize the potential of an off-site release or, in the event of a release, the quantity of the release.

Administrative controls in effect at the COY WPS facility, which were considered to mitigate the severity of the worst-case and alternative release scenarios, include COY?s policies and procedures for training of operators and maintenance personnel, procedures for control of the inventory of chlorine at the facility, and policies regarding quality level of replacement materials and components for the chlorine systems.  Active mitigation measures include timely response of properly trained and equipped personnel who will be following the established emergency response procedures.  

Other mitigation measures in place at the facility include:
? Placement of the chlorine systems (including all cylinders stored) in a dedicated room, which is secure and fire rated;
? A SCADA computer system that alerts the operators when specific system problems occur;
? Chlorine gas leak detection sensors and interconnected alarm system for the chlorine process areas;
? Automatic shut-down valves for the chlorine system at the WPS facility (proposed

office, so that the operators have ready accessibility to this information.  In addition, MSDSs are provided to the outside emergency response teams for use in developing emergency response planning and procedures.
 
1.5.1 Process Hazard Analysis (Appendix C of the RMP)

A process hazard analysis (PHAs) was performed for the WPS facility and its regulated process, to identify potential hazards and to produce recommendations that may promote safer operation of these systems and processes.  The PHA is updated at least every 5 years or when significant changes occur.  A team composed of personnel with engineering process operating experience, and a leader with process hazard analyses experience is assembled to analyze the hazards of each process.  PHA What-If Questions and a Hazard Review Checklist were used to perform the analysis (Appendix C of the RMP). Responsibility to resolve the recommendations is assigned to unit personnel and, when appropriate, changes to enhance the safety of the processes are implemented.  The PHA team incorporated information from the site inspection into the responses on the PHA What-If Questions and the Hazard Review Checklist (Appendix C fo the RMP).  

1.5.2 Operating Procedures (Appendix D of the RMP)

COY operators and managers work together to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be safely performed. The operating procedures are used to train employees and serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to be taken during both normal operations and process upsets.

COY personnel develop and maintain operating procedures that cover all phases of operations, including initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup following a turnaround or emergency shutdown.  The most current information is found in the Operations and Maintenance (O & M) Manuals located in the Water Manager offices.  

The A

ppendices also include other relevant information, such as:
? WPS Off-site Consequence Analysis maps showing release scenarios (Appendix A of the RMP) 
? WPS site plans showing critical systems and emergency shutoff locations (Appendix B of the RMP).
? Block Flow, and Process and Instrumentation Diagrams (Appendix D of the RMP).

When important information is not available from the design documents, it should be developed through special projects or, in the case of operating parameters, during the process hazards analyses.  Many of the operating parameters are included in the operating procedures to help with the safe operation of the process.  These documents are used to train employees, to perform process hazards analyses, and to help maintain the equipment.

1.5.3 Training (Appendix E of the RMP)

COY has permits to operate their facilities, and COY's water treatment operators are certified for operating facilities with chlorine processes, so they can safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks.  Training programs for the operators cover the properties of the substances and the hazards of those substances.  The training programs also include orientation to the layout and operation of the chlorine process at each facility.  Specific operators are required to pass the state certification exam and complete a specified number of continuing education units related to the water treatment plant operations on an ongoing basis.  In addition, safety meetings are held annually, at a minimum.  

Training is provided for COY water treatment operators covering the use of full-face supplied air respirators and personal protective equipment (PPE); chlorine safety; safe cylinder changing procedures; and understanding MSDS sheets.  Training is documented and kept on file at the Water Managers office.  In 2005, COY?s responders and the COY Fire Department conducted emergency response training.  Additionally, COY personnel viewed the chlorine safety CD that was supplied by P

ioneer. 

1.5.4 Mechanical Integrity (Appendix F of the RMP) 

COY has established a mechanical integrity program for the chlorine processes at their WPS facility.  The purpose of the mechanical integrity program is to ensure that all vessels, piping, instrumentation, and other components essential to the containment of this material are designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of an accidental release.  The elements of COY?s mechanical integrity program for chlorine include:

? Identification and categorization of equipment and instrumentation, 
? Maintenance procedures, 
? Training of maintenance personnel, 
? Defined inspection and test procedures and frequencies, 
? Documentation of test and inspection results, and 
? A quality assurance program to help ensure that equipment is designed, fabricated, and installed properly.

1.5.5 Pre-startup Review (Appendix G of the RMP)

COY performs a Pre-Startup Safety Review of all new or modified process prior to the introduction of a regulated material, to ensure that the system will operate safely.  This review confirms:

? Construction is in accordance with specifications;
? Appropriate testing and inspections have been performed;
? Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and adequate;
? Safety Review recommendations have been addressed and actions required for startup have been completed; and
? Operating procedures are in place and training of personnel has been completed.

1.5.6 Management of Change (Appendix H of the RMP)

COY?s Management of Change (MoC) program evaluates and approves all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, and procedures for a covered process, to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations.  Process changes that are determined to be a replacement in kind (e.g., replacing a valve with an identical valve) are allowed without implementing the full MoC program.  All major changes to the regulated processes must

be confirmed through the MoC program, in order to ensure that inadvertent consequences of process changes are prevented, safety consequences of changes are addressed, affected process safety information and procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the changes.  Regulated equipment or process changes completed by a chlorine process specialist will not require the full MoC procedures. 

1.5.7 Compliance Audit (Appendix I of the RMP)

A Compliance Audit (CA) was conducted for the regulated facility from March through August of 2005 to determine whether the prevention program is effectively addressing the safety issues of the operations.  COY assembled an audit team that included personnel knowledgeable in the RMP Rule and in the regulated processes; and this team evaluated whether the prevention program satisfies the requirement of the RMP Rule, and whether it is sufficient to ensure safe operation of the processes.  

1.5.8 Incident Investigation (Appendix J of the RMP)

COY will investigate all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment, so that similar accidents can be prevented.  COY provides training to employees in order to identify and report any incident requiring investigation. An investigation team will be assembled, and the investigation will be initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation will be documented, recommendations will be presented and reviewed, and appropriate process enhancements will be implemented.

1.5.9 Employee Participation Program (Appendix K of the RMP)

COY has developed an employee participation program to help ensure that the safety concerns of its process workers are properly addressed.  COY encourages active participation of its personnel in the prevention program.  Specific employees that work with or around the chlorine processes are consulted and informed about the RMProgram, including PHAs and standard operat

ing procedures.

1.5.10 Hot Work Procedures (Appendix L of the RMP)

COY has established hot work procedures to monitor and control spark- or flame-producing activities that could result in fires or explosions within the regulated process areas.  COY will utilize hot work procedures to comply with California OSHA requirements.  Contractors or process specialists who perform hot work within the chlorine process areas are required to be familiar with COY?s hot work procedures.  Additionally, the responsible managers/supervisors periodically review COY?s hot work procedures to be sure they are adequate.  Training in the use of the hot work procedures is included in COY?s safe work practices orientation.

1.5.11 Contractor Safety (Appendix M of the RMP)

COY established a program to help ensure that contractor activities at the WPS facility are performed in a safe manner.  COY explains to the contract supervisor the hazards of the process on which they and their employees will be working, safe work practices, and proper emergency response procedures.  COY personnel inspect contractor work activities when working in and around the WPS chlorine process areas to help ensure that safe work practices are followed.  COY only utilizes contractors or process specialists that are familiar with their processes and facilities, and have the knowledge and training to perform their duties effectively and safely.
                                                                                                                                                                                           1.6 Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

In addition to the required prevention program elements, COY has implemented safety features specific to the chlorine gas processes utilized at the WPS facility.  These features are further described in the following paragraphs.

At the WPS facility, chlorine is stored in DOT-approved cylinders, which are supplied by Pioneer (541) 397-6136.  COY employs

certified chlorine process specialists and engineers to design, maintain, and service COY?s chlorine control systems and related equipment.  On February 8, 2005, Pioneer conducted a site visit, and on March 4, 2005 they provided COY with a list of safety recommendations, which are in the process of being implemented.  Pioneer also assists COY in implementation of its preventative maintenance program, and as required, they will make repairs and/or install new process equipment, or replace existing equipment if found to be defective or worn.  

COY?s WPS facility has chlorine gas leak detectors located near the floor in the chlorine process room, which will signal those that monitor the SCADA computer system, and also any on-site personnel.  If these alarms are not acknowledged within a specific time, the on-call operators are called at their contact number outside of work and notified. The on-call operators are within a 25 to 45-minute response time of any of COY?s facilities.    

COY has plans to install emergency shut down systems at the WPS on-line chlorine cylinders.  Automatic shut-off valves will be located on the downstream side of the flexible pigtail connection at each cylinder that will shut down the systems upon sensing low pressure in the piping downstream from this valve.  If a release occurs downstream of the vacuum switchover valve (vacuum loss), the valve will close and only the quantity in the piping will be released.  Air-supplied respirators are located outside the chlorine process areas at each facility (see map, Appendix B of the RMP).

At the WPS facility, two one-ton chlorine cylinders are strapped onto their saddle supports, which are bolted to the slab (per design drawings).  Additionally, a ventilation system can be energized if a chlorine gas leak has been detected.   

At the WPS facility, process piping systems and supports appear to be installed per the required standards, and pipe supports are securely mounted to solid structures.  Th

e cylinders and gas piping systems are located within areas that will secure them from large objects, which could fall and damage the cylinders or supply system.  Equipment inspections are regularly conducted and recorded by operational staff.  Flexible pigtail connections are used, and the chlorine use and storage rooms have a chlorine gas leak detector with a backup notification system.

When transporting a one-ton cylinder, the valve cover remains in place, the cylinders are loaded and unloaded utilizing the proper equipment, and the cylinder are set into a saddle support and strapped in place.  Only trained employees complete the cylinder transfer process, and adhere to strict guidelines when completing this process.
                                                                                                                                                                                           1.7 Five-Year Accident History (Section 5.0 of the RMP)

COY has reported no accidents, personal injuries, or property damage in the last five years, with regard to a release of chlorine gas.  If an incident occurs, an investigation team will conduct an investigation, following the incident investigation protocol.  The team will suggest improvements to the process and, if appropriate, improvements will be made.  Additionally, a report will be completed and will be kept on file at the Water Managers office.

1.8 Emergency Response Program (Section 8.0 of the RMP)

COY has established a written emergency response program to ensure a safe response to an accidental release of chlorine gas.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for: 

? Fires 
? Medical Emergencies
? Earthquakes, Disasters
? Emergency Spills or Releases

As per safety recommendations by Pioneer and SHN, COY is in the process of updating their emergency response training, and conducting OSHA hazardous materials training for its process personnel and responders.  Pioneer and SHN have conducted s

ite visits and safety reviews with COY, and Pioneer provided COY with a training CD to help meet the OSHA requirements.  In 2005, COY?s key personnel and the COY Fire Department conducted emergency response training.  

Additional emergency response, and health and safety training will be conducted since the SCHMRT (certified and trained responders) have a response time that may be 2 hours or more.  During the planned emergency response training all affected COY personnel, COY?s Fire and Police Departments, the SCHMRT, and the SCEHD will be provided with the emergency response plan and procedures.

1.9 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

COY constantly strives to improve the safety of the regulated processes, through both the incident investigation program and the practice of encouraging safety suggestions for improvement from the workers.  COY?s preventative maintenance program also helps ensure that the equipment and processes are operating in a safe and efficient manner.

The WFP facility is visited daily by a COY operator. Automatic shut-off valves are planned to be installed at both on-line chlorine supply systems.  As per recent safety recommendations, COY is in the process of updating its emergency response and OSHA training program.
